metadata.guideline_reference: KNGF Guideline on Stroke (2014), European Stroke Guidelines

patient_profile.name: Maria van den Berg
patient_profile.living_situation: Lives with husband (72, healthy) in two-story house, bedroom upstairs
patient_profile.hobbies: Gardening, reading, weekly bridge club, caring for grandchildren
patient_profile.referral_reason: Inpatient rehabilitation following left MCA ischemic stroke

medical_information.diagnosis: Left middle cerebral artery (MCA) ischemic stroke
medical_information.imaging: CT: Left MCA territory infarct involving motor cortex and corona radiata
medical_information.thrombolysis: tPA administered within 3 hours of symptom onset
medical_history: Atrial fibrillation (newly diagnosed at stroke onset)

session_1_initial_assessment.patient_narrative: I woke up and couldn't move my right side. My husband called the ambulance. I was so scared - I thought I was dying. The doctors say I had a stroke. My right arm still doesn't work properly, and I'm worried I'll never be able to hold my grandchildren again or work in my garden. I've always been independent and I don't want to be a burden on Hans.
patient_goals_stated: Walk without needing someone to hold me
Use my right hand to hold things
Go back home - I don't want to go to a nursing home
Be able to play with my grandchildren

family_input.husband_concerns: Will she be able to manage the stairs at home? I want to help but I have a bad back myself.
family_input.family_support: Two adult children living nearby, willing to help with care and transport

observation.posture_sitting: Sitting balance fair, tends to list to right (pushing behavior minimal)
observation.facial_expression: Right lower facial droop, able to close eyes symmetrically
observation.upper_limb_position: Right arm held in flexion synergy pattern at rest
observation.alertness: Alert, oriented to person/place/time, mild attention deficits

motricity_index.interpretation: Moderate impairment UL, mild-moderate impairment LL

synergy_patterns.upper_limb: Flexor synergy dominant - shoulder abduction/external rotation limited, elbow extension weak
synergy_patterns.lower_limb: Emerging out of extensor synergy, some selective hip flexion possible

modified_ashworth_scale.interpretation: Mild spasticity emerging, monitor for increase

sensory_assessment.light_touch: Diminished right arm and leg (can detect but not localize)
sensory_assessment.proprioception: Impaired at right wrist and fingers, intact at elbow and ankle
sensory_assessment.clinical_implication: Sensory deficits will affect motor learning and safety

trunk_control_test.interpretation: Fair trunk control, good prognostic sign

balance_assessment.sitting_balance: Independent static, requires supervision for dynamic reaching
balance_assessment.standing_balance: Requires moderate assistance, weight shift to right limited

mobility_assessment.bed_mobility: Modified independent with bedrail, rolls to left better than right

transfers.technique: Leads with left, difficulty weight-shifting to right

gait.fac_description: Dependent on physical assistance (level I) - needs continuous support of one person
gait.pattern: Circumduction right leg, decreased right stance time, foot drop requiring AFO
gait.assistive_device: Quad cane + AFO, moderate assistance x1

mobility_assessment.stairs: Not yet assessed - insufficient balance and strength

action_research_arm_test.interpretation: Severe limitation, some grasp possible but no functional use

upper_limb_function.functional_use: Unable to use right hand for ADLs, uses left hand for all tasks
upper_limb_function.voluntary_movement: Can initiate shoulder flexion in synergy, minimal isolated finger movement

cognitive_screening.implications: Cognitive deficits may affect learning, need clear simple instructions

communication.language_comprehension: Intact for simple and complex commands

positive_factors: Good trunk control (TCT 74 - predicts walking ability)
Lower limb stronger than upper limb
negative_factors: Age 68 (older age associated with slower recovery)

safe_score_walking.factors: Age, initial leg strength, trunk control
safe_score_walking.prediction: Good probability of independent walking within 3 months (TCT >50 is strong predictor)

epos_upper_limb.factors: Day 2 shoulder abduction and finger extension
epos_upper_limb.limitation: Not fully applicable at day 12, but minimal finger extension is concerning for UL recovery

prognostic_indicators.clinical_reasoning_note: Prognosis for walking is good based on TCT and LL strength. UL functional recovery less certain - focus on compensation strategies while continuing to work on recovery.

environmental_factors.description: Design of buildings for private use (stairs at home)

personal_factors.motivation: High - very motivated to return home and resume activities
personal_factors.fear: Worried about being a burden, fear of nursing home
personal_factors.self_efficacy: Currently low but willing to work hard

problems.activity_limitation: Unable to transfer independently (sit-to-stand, bed-chair) - requires moderate assistance x1
underlying_impairments: Right lower limb weakness (MRC hip flexion 3, knee extension 4)
Impaired balance and weight shift to right
Reduced trunk control for dynamic tasks
problems.participation_impact: Cannot be left alone safely, requires caregiver presence

problems.activity_limitation: Unable to walk independently - FAC 2, requires continuous physical assistance
underlying_impairments: Right LE weakness with foot drop
problems.participation_impact: Dependent for all mobility, cannot access community

problems.activity_limitation: Unable to use right hand for any functional tasks (ARAT 12/57)
underlying_impairments: Flexor synergy pattern limiting selective movement
problems.participation_impact: Cannot care for grandchildren, gardening not possible, needs help with all bimanual tasks
Cannot access bedroom in current home - major barrier to discharge

goals.discharge_criteria: Safe discharge home with husband as primary caregiver, community support in place

long_term_goal.goal: Discharge home with supervision-level mobility, independent transfers, and strategies to manage ADLs with one-handed techniques

short_term_goals.goal: Perform sit-to-stand transfer with standby assistance only, using appropriate technique
Walk 20 meters with quad cane and standby assistance (FAC 3)
Walk 50 meters with quad cane independently on level surfaces (FAC 4)
Initiate voluntary right shoulder flexion to 90° with gravity eliminated (out of synergy)
Independently perform grooming and feeding using one-handed techniques and adaptive equipment
Negotiate 12 stairs with rail and supervision (to access bedroom)

intervention_plan.treatment_approach: Task-specific, high-intensity, repetitive practice with focus on functional goals. Compensation where recovery limited, but continue to challenge motor recovery.

interventions.intervention: Task-specific overground gait training with appropriate assistance and AFO
interventions.rationale: Repetitive, task-specific practice drives neuroplasticity. Walking is the priority functional goal.
interventions.progression: Decrease assistance, increase distance, add challenges (turns, obstacles)

interventions.intervention: Progressive balance exercises - static to dynamic, supported to unsupported
interventions.rationale: Balance is prerequisite for safe mobility. Weight-shifting to affected side critical.
interventions.progression: Sitting → Standing with support → Standing unsupported → Reaching → Perturbations

interventions.intervention: Progressive resistance training for affected lower limb
Repetitive task practice, constraint considerations, electrical stimulation if appropriate
interventions.rationale: Some voluntary movement present - maximize recovery potential while teaching compensation
interventions.approach: Combine recovery-focused exercises with one-handed technique training
interventions.evidence: Moderate (CIMT criteria not met due to minimal hand function)

interventions.dosage: Integrated into all sessions, aim for 30+ repetitions/day

interventions.progression: Step-to pattern with rail → Step-over pattern → Decreased reliance on rail

interventions.intervention: One-handed technique training and adaptive equipment
interventions.rationale: Maximize independence while UL recovery continues

interventions.intervention: Patient and family education on stroke recovery, home exercise, safety
interventions.rationale: Prepare for discharge, set realistic expectations, involve husband in care

intensity_considerations.patient_factors: Age and cardiac history - monitor for fatigue, appropriate rest breaks

multidisciplinary_team.physiotherapy: Mobility, balance, gait, LL strengthening, transfers, stairs
multidisciplinary_team.occupational_therapy: UL function, ADL training, home assessment, equipment
multidisciplinary_team.social_work: Discharge planning, community services, family support

key_issues: Stairs to bedroom - can patient manage or need stairlift/bedroom relocation?
Bathroom accessibility - rails, shower seat needed
Husband's capacity to assist (has back problems)
equipment_recommendations: Quad cane or rollator for home
Consider stairlift if stairs remain difficult

husband_training: Standby assistance for transfers and stairs
Recognition of warning signs (new stroke symptoms)

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.trap: Neglecting upper limb because recovery is uncertain
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Focusing only on mobility and ignoring UL rehabilitation
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: The patient has some voluntary UL movement. What does the evidence say about UL rehabilitation intensity? How can you balance recovery-focused and compensation approaches?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Promising full UL recovery despite poor prognostic signs
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: What prognostic indicators help predict UL recovery? How do you set hopeful but realistic goals with this patient?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Focusing only on impairments without considering home context
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: How do the stairs at home affect your goal setting? What needs to happen for safe discharge?
What does the evidence say about rehabilitation intensity after stroke? How can you maximize practice opportunities?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.trap: Ignoring the husband as part of the team
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Not involving caregiver in rehabilitation and planning
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: The husband will be the primary caregiver at home. How are you involving him in the rehabilitation process?

step_1_data_collection: What prognostic indicators did you identify? What do they suggest about recovery potential?
How does the Motricity Index score help you understand the difference between UL and LL prognosis?
What does the Trunk Control Test score tell you about walking prognosis?
How do the home environment factors affect your assessment?
step_2_problem_statements: You've listed 'right hemiparesis' as a problem - is this an impairment or activity limitation?
How does the inability to manage stairs affect discharge planning?
What is the relationship between the sensory deficits and the motor problems?
step_3_goal_setting: How did you decide on the FAC goal of 4? What evidence supports this as achievable?
Your UL goal focuses on impairment - how does this connect to a functional goal?
Have you discussed these goals with the patient? Do they align with her priorities?
step_4_intervention_selection: What is your rationale for the gait training approach?
How will you ensure sufficient intensity and repetition?
Why did you choose this particular balance exercise progression?
step_7_reevaluation: When would you re-administer outcome measures?
If the patient isn't progressing as expected at week 2, what would you consider?
How will you know when the patient is ready to practice stairs?
